Get started

Source: vignettes/r2dii.Rmd
r2dii.Rmd

This article details most features.

As usual, start using the r2dii.dataraw package with:

library(r2dii)
#> Loading required package: r2dii.dataprep
#> Loading required package: r2dii.dataraw
#> Loading required package: r2dii.utils

Creating data snapshots

take_snapshot() takes a snapshot of all possible datasets. By default it does not overwrite existing snapshots, and warns if it fails to take a snapshot of expected datasets.

take_snapshot()
#> Wrote 'config.yml' to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/config.yml'.
#> Wrote `BENCH.REGIONS` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/BENCH.REGIONS.csv'.
#> Wrote `BicsSectorBridge` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/BicsSectorBridge.csv'.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'readr':
#>   method           from 
#>   format.col_spec  vroom
#>   print.col_spec   vroom
#>   print.collector  vroom
#>   print.date_names vroom
#>   print.locale     vroom
#>   str.col_spec     vroom
#> Warning in gzfile(file, "rb"): cannot open compressed file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck/00_Data/02_FinancialData/2018Q4/Fund Data/
#> FundsData2018Q4.rda', probable reason 'No such file or directory'
#> Wrote `GROUPS.GOVT` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/GROUPS.GOVT.txt'.
#> Wrote `INDEX.REGIONS` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/INDEX.REGIONS.csv'.
#> Warning in gzfile(file, "rb"): cannot open compressed file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck/00_Data/01_ProcessedData/01_SectorMasters/
#> 201812/PortCheck_MasterData_Risk_Debt.rda', probable reason 'No such file
#> or directory'
#> Warning in gzfile(file, "rb"): cannot open compressed file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck/00_Data/01_ProcessedData/01_SectorMasters/
#> 201812/PortCheck_MasterData_Risk_Ownership.rda', probable reason 'No such
#> file or directory'
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Wrote `SectorBridge` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/SectorBridge.csv'.
#> Wrote `TYPE.EQUITY` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/TYPE.EQUITY.txt'.
#> Wrote `TYPE.OTHERS` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/TYPE.OTHERS.txt'.
#> Wrote `sector.bridge` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/sector.bridge.csv'.
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> ALD.BV, ALD.CB, ALD.CC, ALD.Company, ALD.EQ, ALD.SPV, BALANCE.SHEET.DATA, CB_OG, DebtMarket, DebtMarketClimate, EQMarket.Size, EQ_OG, FIN.DATA, Fund.Data, FundsTrusts, Indices, LoanMarket, LoanMarketClimate, PHYSICAL.RISK.CB, PHYSICAL.RISK.EQ, Receipts, SCEN, SCENLong, SEC.TYPE.BONDS, TYPE.BONDS, TYPE.RECEIPTS

You can snapshot specific datasets.

possible_snapshots() shows you all possible snapshots.

possible_snapshots()
#>  [1] "ALD.BV"             "ALD.CB"             "ALD.CC"            
#>  [4] "ALD.Company"        "ALD.EQ"             "ALD.SPV"           
#>  [7] "BALANCE.SHEET.DATA" "BENCH.REGIONS"      "BicsSectorBridge"  
#> [10] "CB_OG"              "DebtMarket"         "DebtMarketClimate" 
#> [13] "EQMarket.Size"      "EQ_OG"              "FIN.DATA"          
#> [16] "Fund.Data"          "FundsTrusts"        "GROUPS.GOVT"       
#> [19] "INDEX.REGIONS"      "Indices"            "LoanMarket"        
#> [22] "LoanMarketClimate"  "PHYSICAL.RISK.CB"   "PHYSICAL.RISK.EQ"  
#> [25] "Receipts"           "RevenueSplit"       "SCEN"              
#> [28] "SCENLong"           "SEC.TYPE.BONDS"     "SectorBridge"      
#> [31] "TYPE.BONDS"         "TYPE.EQUITY"        "TYPE.OTHERS"       
#> [34] "TYPE.RECEIPTS"      "sector.bridge"

overwrite = TRUE allows you to overwrite existing snapshots.

specific_datasets <- c("RevenueSplit", "EQMarket.Size")

specific_datasets %>% 
  take_snapshot(overwrite = TRUE)
#> Wrote 'config.yml' to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/config.yml'.
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to '/home/travis/build/2DegreesInvesting/r2dii/inst/extdata/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> EQMarket.Size

By default the snapshots are stored in a special directory of the package. (Files in this special directory automatically install in your system when you install the package).

destdir allows you to customize the destination directory.

a_directory <- tempdir()

specific_datasets %>% 
  take_snapshot(destdir = a_directory)
#> Wrote 'config.yml' to '/tmp/RtmpgCsK7v/config.yml'.
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to '/tmp/RtmpgCsK7v/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> EQMarket.Size

By default the snapshots are created with a configuration file stored in the same directory where the package is installed.

default_config()
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config.yml"

edit_config() allows you to edit the default configuration file.

if (interactive()) edit_config()

If you are on an interactive session a file should open that looks like this:

default_config() %>% 
  show_config(n_max = 10)
#> default:
#>   Methodology:
#>     HasBookValue: FALSE # ignore
#>     HasRISK: TRUE # ignore a flag specifying if the physical risk assessment should be done
#>     HasMAP: TRUE # flag to specify if map data (production per country) should be prepared
#>     HasSB: FALSE # ignore for now
#> 
#>   TimeStamps:
#>     # setting the dates of the data-input for financial and asset-level data: this identifies the input files
#>     FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q4 # specifies the Financial data sourcing date ie from which date the financial information is taken

(I showed only n_max lines to save space.)

You can use a custom configuration file.

custom_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")
custom_config
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config-toy.yml"

custom_config %>% 
  show_config()
#> default:
#>   Expect:
#>    param_a: a
#>    param_1: 1
#>    param_true: TRUE
#>    param_false: FALSE
#>    param_unset:
#>   TimeStamps:
#>     ALD.Timestamp: 3333
#>     FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q3

config allows you to use a custom configuration file with take_snapshot().

specific_datasets %>% 
  take_snapshot(destdir = a_directory, config = custom_config)
#> Wrote 'config-toy.yml' to '/tmp/RtmpgCsK7v/config-toy.yml'.
#> Skipping existing snapshot of `RevenueSplit`.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> EQMarket.Size

options("r2dii_config") allows you to provide a custom configuration file to be used globally.

getOption("r2dii_config")
#> NULL

# Set new options and store old options to restore them later
restore_options <- options(r2dii_config = custom_config)

getOption("r2dii_config")
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config-toy.yml"

take_snapshot() will now use the custom configuration file.

specific_datasets %>% 
  take_snapshot(destdir = a_directory)
#> Skipping existing snapshot of 'config-toy.yml'.
#> Skipping existing snapshot of `RevenueSplit`.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> EQMarket.Size

options() affect your R session globally; you set this option once an many other functions can use it.

get_config()
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config-toy.yml"

if (interactive()) edit_config()

# You'll see something like this
show_config(get_config())
#> default:
#>   Expect:
#>    param_a: a
#>    param_1: 1
#>    param_true: TRUE
#>    param_false: FALSE
#>    param_unset:
#>   TimeStamps:
#>     ALD.Timestamp: 3333
#>     FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q3

Restore the original options to go back to using the custom configuration file.

options(restore_options)

specific_datasets %>% 
  take_snapshot(destdir = a_directory)
#> Skipping existing snapshot of 'config.yml'.
#> Skipping existing snapshot of `RevenueSplit`.
#> Warning in file(file, "rt"): cannot open file '/home/travis/
#> Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck_v2/10_Projects/0_MarketPortfolios/
#> 21_EQMarketSize_Inputs/EQMarketSizeBasedOnIndices.csv': No such file or
#> directory
#> Warning: Can't write the following datasets:
#> EQMarket.Size

Documentation

You can access the high level documentation of the package with ?r2dii.dataraw. At the bottom you may click Index to access the help files of all topics. As usual, you can access the help file of any topic with ?topic.

A good way to learn about all features is to explore the “r2dii.dataraw” tab of the private package-website:

if (interactive()) browse_private_site()

Please help me improve the documentation via pull requests.

Create paths

A family of functions create robust paths.

path_dropbox_2dii()
#> /home/travis/Dropbox (2° Investing)

For this to work, you must have the Dropbox folder of 2dii directly under home (the default location).

fs::dir_ls(fs::path_home(), regexp = "Dropbox")
#> character(0)

Configuration file

A family of functions help you to deal with the configuration file.

edit_config() opens the default configuration file so you can edit it.

if (interactive()) edit_config()

(I’m not in an interactive session so the chunk above won’t run.)

get_config() outputs a path to a configuration file. By default it outputs the path to the default configuration file – stored in the r2dii.dataraw package.

get_config()
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config.yml"

show_config() shows a configuration file.

show_config(get_config(), n_max = 10)
default:
  Methodology:
    HasBookValue: FALSE # ignore
    HasRISK: TRUE # ignore a flag specifying if the physical risk assessment should be done
    HasMAP: TRUE # flag to specify if map data (production per country) should be prepared
    HasSB: FALSE # ignore for now

  TimeStamps:
    # setting the dates of the data-input for financial and asset-level data: this identifies the input files
    FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q4 # specifies the Financial data sourcing date ie from which date the financial information is taken

You can change the default configuration file globally via options().

your_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")
restore <- options(r2dii_config = your_config)

get_config()
[1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config-toy.yml"

show_config(get_config())
default:
  Expect:
   param_a: a
   param_1: 1
   param_true: TRUE
   param_false: FALSE
   param_unset:
  TimeStamps:
    ALD.Timestamp: 3333
    FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q3

options(restore)

Access configuration parameters and create configuration-sensitive paths

A family of functions are sensitive to the configuration file you use. This includes all functions to access configuration parameters, and some of the functions to create paths.

# Using the default configuration file
getOption("r2dii_config")
#> NULL
FINANCIAL.TIMESTAMP()
#> [1] "2018Q4"
FIN.DATA.PATH()
#> /home/travis/Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck/00_Data/02_FinancialData/2018Q4

# Using your configuration file
your_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")
restore <- options(r2dii_config = your_config)
FINANCIAL.TIMESTAMP()
#> [1] "2018Q3"
FIN.DATA.PATH()
#> /home/travis/Dropbox (2° Investing)/PortCheck/00_Data/02_FinancialData/2018Q3

options(restore)

Extending functions to access configuration parameters

Eventually you will likely need to access new configuration parameters. How would you expand this family of functions?

Use get_param() to create new functions to access configuration parameters.

# Create a `get_a_value()` function to get `a_value` from `a_field`
get_a_value <- get_param("a_field")

# Create an example configuration file
config <- glue::glue("
   default:
     a_field: a_value
 ")

show_config(config)
  default:
    a_field: a_value
# Write the config file to a temporary file
config_file <- tempfile()
readr::write_lines(config, config_file)

get_a_value(file = config_file)
#> [1] "a_value"

Datasets

A family of functions allow you to read local datasets from your local 2dii Dropbox-folder, e.g.:

# Not showing this for privacy
ALD.BV()

A family of datasets become directly available when you attach the r2dii.dataraw package, e.g.:

INDEX.REGIONS
#> # A tibble: 327 x 3
#>    EquityMarket Country             CountryISO
#>    <chr>        <chr>               <chr>     
#>  1 Global       Afghanistan         AF        
#>  2 Global       Albania             AL        
#>  3 Global       Algeria             DZ        
#>  4 Global       American Samoa      AS        
#>  5 Global       Andorra             AD        
#>  6 Global       Angola              AO        
#>  7 Global       Anguilla            AI        
#>  8 Global       Antigua And Barbuda AG        
#>  9 Global       Argentina           AR        
#> 10 Global       Armenia             AM        
#> # … with 317 more rows

GROUPS.GOVT
#>  [1] "Sovereign"              "Sovereign Agency"      
#>  [3] "Municipal"              "Municipal-City"        
#>  [5] "Municipal-County"       "Multi-National"        
#>  [7] "Regional"               "Regional(state/provnc)"
#>  [9] "Export/Import Bank"     "Regional Authority"    
#> [11] "Regional Agencies"

Some datasets are sensitive to the configuration file, which you can always check with get_config().

get_config()
#> [1] "/home/travis/R/Library/r2dii.utils/config.yml"
